I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2002 review of the Country Strategy and Program Update, the Government of 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) reconfirmed its request for ADB to provide technical 
assistance (TA) to prepare a project for Sanjiang Plains wetland protection.1 A Fact-Finding 
Mission visited the PRC on 9-23 September 2002 and reached an understanding with the 
Heilongjiang Provincial Government (HPG) and the Central Government on the objectives, 
scope, cost estimates, financing plan,  and implementation arrangements of the TA.2 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  While there has been a marked reduction in poverty in the PRC, significant numbers of 
people still live below the poverty line. This is particularly true for the remote areas of the 
country, including parts of Heilongjiang Province. The PRC needs to continue its focus on 
generating inclusive and equitable economic growth and to undertake pro-poor policy measures 
to  help  ensure  that  the  poor  benefit  from  future  economic  development.  Sustainability  of 
development through appropriate management of natural resources, and consequently, the 
stability of the environment, is part of the war on poverty, since the poor are most vulnerable to 
environmental degradation.  
 
3.  The Sanjiang Plains, in the northeast of Heilongjiang Province, are bordered by two 
rivers–the Heilongjiang in the north and northwest, and the Wusulijiang in the east. These 
constitute the two major flood plains in the Songhua river basin. These plains, with a population 
of about 8 million, extend over 100,000 square kilometers. The area includes extensive forests 
and plantations covering over 19 million hectares (ha), and the single largest wetland area in the 
PRC, spreading over 2 million ha.  These wetlands are important because of their ability to 
absorb floods and regulate flows in the rivers, two of which form international borders with the 
Russian Federation. Furthermore, these wetlands act as natural filters for silt and dissolved 
pollutants, support major agricultural activities, and are habitat for globally significant flora and 
fauna. 
 
4.  The Sanjiang Plains wetlands, extending over 37 ecosystems, support more than 1,400 
species of flora and more than 1,000 species of fauna, including the globally significant and 
endangered sturgeon.3 To protect this biodiversity, six of the protected areas in the Sanjiang 
Plains have been declared as national nature reserves (NNRs): (i) Xingkaihu (Mishan City), (ii) 
Honghe (Fuyuan County and Tongjiang City), (iii) Black Bee (Raohe County), (iv) Sanjiang 
(Fuyuan County and Tongjiang City), (v) Qixinghe (Baoqing County), and (vi) Naolihe (Baoqing 
County and Raohe County).  Three of these–Xingkaihu, Honghe, and Sanjiang–have been 
listed as the ramsar sites.4  The Black Bee NNR in the Wasulijiang River basin along the Sino-

Russian border is significant from an ecological and socioeconomic point of view. Over 140 
plants in the forests and wetlands in the basin provide an ideal habitat for the bees. The honey 
produced is considered to be of the best quality in the PRC and has been certified by the 
European Union Organic Food Organization. Beekeeping farmers earn up to Y4,800 annually 
(about $580 equivalent) from 10-12 beehives. However, survival of this species and the ensuing 
economic  benefits  are  threatened  by  indiscriminate  logging  in  the  area  and  inadequate 
protection of blackbee host trees.  
 
5.  Local communities within the Sanjiang Plains rely on biological resources for food, 
energy, fodder, and raw materials for subsistence and manufacturing. Biological resources such 
as reeds, fish, and waterfowl are commercially exploited and serve as a source of income for 
these communities. Because of traditional reliance on these biological resources, there is a 
close relationship between community well-being and access to these resources. 
 
6.  Since the1950s, the Sanjiang Plains have experienced large-scale deforestation and 
conversion into agriculture and state-owned enterprises, mostly for farming. As part of this 
conversion process, an extensive drainage system was constructed beginning in the late 1970s. 
Roads, highways, urbanization, and industrialization have made further inroads into the frontier, 
exacerbating the detrimental impact on the ecological functions and productive potential of the 
nature reserves and wetlands.  
 
7.  New government policies and plans are aimed at halting and reversing environmental 
degradation  in  the  area.  Just  completed  master  plans  call  for  delineation  and  effective 
management of core and buffer zones, restriction of economic activities to the experimental 
zones,5 ban on new development activities in the wetlands, and resettlement of people living in 
core and buffer zones.6 Resettlement will affect the life and well-being of the communities, and 
will have to be linked to sustainable livelihoods and employment generation.  
 
8.  Forestland in the Sanjiang Plains covers about 11 million ha, with 1.142 million ha 
managed by the Provincial Forestry Department (PFD). Commercial plantations of fast-growing 
species cover 50,000 ha of this area, and 17,000 ha are available for new plantations. Because 
management of these plantations is not in line with scientific principles, they have not realized 
their potential in terms of growth and quality. Consequently, a potentially self-sustaining sector 
is not delivering a satisfactory output. The sector should be managed on scientific principles to 
increase production and to ensure sustainable supplies of high-quality raw materials for the 
industry. Given good soil conditions, there is  potential  for  agroforestry  as  an  income  and 
employment generation activity, both on farmers’ land and on PFD-managed land.  
 
9.  A study on sustainable land use in the Sanjiang Plains was undertaken from 1995 to 
1996, with support of the State Development Planning Commission, the Provincial Planning 
Commission, Ecologically Sustainable Development, Inc. (USA), and the National Committee on 
United  States-China  Relations  (USA),  which,  among  other  things,  recommended  highly 
selective conversion of remaining wetlands to farmland, and urged investment in productivity 
improvements in existing farmland.  The study further recommended application to the Ramsar 
Convention Bureau to list parts of the Sanjiang Plains as wetlands of international importance,

3
especially as a waterfowl habitat, and preserving them as the core of the Sanjiang Plains 
International  Peace  Park  and  Wildlife  Refuge.7  In  1999,  United  Nations  Development 
Programme  (UNDP)/Global  Environment  Facility  (GEF)  initiated  the  five-year  Wetland 
Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Use Project aimed at removing barriers to effective 
biodiversity conservation at four representative sites of global biodiversity importance, which 
include the Sanjiang Wetlands and Honghe NNR in the Sanjiang Plains.  
 
10.  Over the past several years, considerable efforts have been made in habitat restoration 
and  conservation  of  the  biodiversity  in  the  Sanjiang  Plains  by  the  national  and  local 
governments. These include (i) National Wetland Conservation Action Plan and establishment 
of a National Wetland Coordinating Committee involving 17 ministries and other government 
agencies, setting out the Government’s commitment to (a) sustainable use and improved 
protection of important wetland sites, (b) increase in the number of Ramsar sites, and (c) reform 
of policies related to wetland protection, (ii) Regulations for the Nature Reserves of Heilongjiang 
Province;  (iii)  establishment  of  the  Northeast  Black  Bee  National  Natural  Reserve;  (iv) 
designation of the National Ecological Demonstration Zone for Northeastern Black Bee; and (v) 
a program for restoration of the sturgeon habitat and its artificial fertilization, hatching, and 
culture.8  
 
11.  Master plans have been prepared for the NNRs  in Heilongjiang Province. While the 
administration and management of the NNRs is under the jurisdiction of PFD, some are still 
under the control of the Environmental Protection Bureau and state-owned farm enterprises, an 
anomaly that needs to be analyzed and addressed. Each nature reserve has been zoned into 
core zone, buffer zone, and experimental zone. This zoning system is in line with international 
norms  and  provides  the  necessary  planning  framework  for  integrating  conservation  and 
development  activities.  This  approach  makes  protection  and  conservation  of  species  and 
biodiversity the dominant management objective within the core zone and the buffer zone, 
whereas economic development is the principal land use and management objective in the 
experimental zone. The NNR master plans require resettlement of people living within the core 
and buffer zones to experimental zones, where opportunities will be provided for sustainable 
and ecologically sound economic development. 
  
12.  Continuation  of  these  initiatives  and  effective  implementation  of  these  plans,  while 
critical for conservation, is constrained by (i) capacity limitations for natural resources and 
biodiversity assessments, management, and monitoring; (ii)  non-availability of financing on 
suitable terms attractive for low financial and high economic return conservation and other 
environmental services’ activities; (iii) limited borrowing capacity of the counties, townships, 
villages,  and  farmers;  (iv)  inadequate  awareness  about  the  significance  and  benefits  of 
conservation-based  development  strategies;  and  (v)  limited  funding  for  research  on  the 
restoration of the habitat for the endangered sturgeon and the black bee. Protecting globally 
significant biodiversity in these plains and addressing the problems of poverty while reducing 
and reversing environmental degradation require a comprehensive and integrated strategy. The 
TA will attempt to do so by identifying appropriate approaches and options for conservation and 
development of the area, which, while maintaining the integrity of the wetland ecosystem, will 
also enhance and diversify livelihood opportunities for the local communities.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
13.  The purpose of the TA is to prepare an investment project for integrated wetland and 
forest conservation and development in the Sanjiang Plains based on their potential to support 
ecologically sustainable economic development; promote conservation and sustainable use of 
biodiversity; and enhance the well-being of local communities, especially the poor.   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will (i) review, and update the mid-term report of the Songhua River Flood, 
Wetland,  and  Biodiversity  Management  Project9; (ii) undertake a social assessment in the 
proposed Project area to measure patterns of settlement, resource use and social organization, 
together with socioeconomic indicators of well-being, and poverty cause analysis to identify 
potential economic activities and required inputs to benefit the poor; (iii) undertake a sector 
analysis to identify constraints, and opportunities in the sustainable and integrated conservation 
of biodiversity and economic development of wetlands and forests; (iv) identify priority sites of 
global biodiversity significance and threats to these sites, and propose activities to conserve 
biodiversity; (v) identify investment options for habitat restoration, commercial forestry, and 
alternative livelihoods that do not compromise biodiversity conservation; (vi) assess and identify 
biophysical and socioeconomic indicators to monitor changes in the biodiversity and integrity of 
nature reserves, and social well-being of the local communities; (vii) analyze the existing legal, 
institutional,  and  policy  environment,  and  formulate  recommendations  for  policy  reform; 
institutional capacity building for integrated conservation and development; and information 
management and monitoring; (viii) based on past experience and lessons learned in the PRC, 
especially the UNDP/GEF National Wetlands Project,  and in other countries in the region, 
prepare  a  Feasibility  Study  report  for  an  investment  plan  for  integrated  conservation  and 
development in the Sanjiang Plains; and (ix) prepare a GEF project brief and appendixes on 
incremental cost analysis, biodiversity threats analysis, and stakeholder involvement plan. The 
team will also review existing institutions policies and legislation in the implementation of various 
international conventions including the Biodiversity Convention and the Ramsar Convention.  
 
15.  The feasibility study will include economic and financial viability, potential environmental 
impacts, mitigation and monitoring of potentially adverse impacts, and the potential impact of 
such investments on social well-being and income levels of local communities, and the impact 
on economic development of the area and the province. See Appendix 1 for Preliminary Project 
Framework.  
C.  Cost  and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000 equivalent, comprising $400,000 in 
foreign exchange and $350,000 equivalent in local currency costs.  ADB will finance $600,000 
equivalent to cover all of the foreign exchange cost plus $200,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund funded by 
the Government of Japan. The Government will contribute the remaining local currency cost of 
$150,000 equivalent. This will include costs of office accommodation and facilities, remuneration 
and per diem of counterpart staff and technical experts, local transportation, and logistical

support for workshops.  The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Executing Agency will be HPG, which will coordinate, guide, and supervise all 
activities pertaining to implementation. To carry out these responsibilities, HPG has a provincial 
leading group (LG) chaired by the executive vice governor in charge of HPG foreign capital 
utilization operations. LG members include heads of the Heilongjiang Development Planning 
Commission (HDPC), the Heilongjiang Financial Department (HFD), the Heilongjiang Auditing 
Office, and other concerned agencies. The LG will be the policy making body and will be 
responsible  for  providing  guidance  to  coordinate  the  roles  of  provincial  agencies  and  the 
municipal and county governments. For implementation, the vice commissioner of HDPC will be 
the director of the project management office (PMO) under the leadership of the provincial LG. 
Deputy directors of the PMO will come from HDPC and HFD. Members of the PMO will include 
representatives  of  HDPC,  HFD,  the  Environmental  Protection  Bureau  (EPB),  PFD,  the 
Agricultural Commission, and the Livestock Bureau.   
 
18.    The TA will require 53 person-months of consulting services: 16 person-months of 
international and 37 person-months of domestic consultants (see Appendix 2 for the specific 
expertise to be provided in each group). Consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  for  the  selection  and 
engagement of domestic consultants. Given the highly technical nature of the TA, quality-based 
selection on the basis of full technical proposals to be submitted by consulting firms will be 
adopted. Procurement will follow the ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The TA is expected to 
commence in March 2003 and completed in August 2003. Outline terms of reference are 
attached as Appendix 3.  
 
19.  The consultants will produce three reports, which will be discussed at tripartite meetings. 
These include (i) an inception report, which will include a logical framework and a work program, 
(ii) a midterm report, with an updated logical framework and work program providing detailed 
information and analysis of various options for investment; (iii) a draft final report, which will 
include the objectives; scope; social, environmental, and economic analyses; implementation 
arrangements; cost estimates and financing plan; and other relevant details of the investment 
project; and (iv) a final report of the feasibility study, incorporating the comments on the draft 
final report.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Sanjiang Plains Wetland 
Protection Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
1.  The objective of the ensuing Sanjiang Plains Wetland Protection project is to protect and 
conserve the globally significant biodiversity of the Sanjiang plains in Heilongjiang Province, 
using an integrated conservation and economic development (ICED) approach. The ICED 
approach will include (i) income generation activities for the local communities outside of the 
nature reserves; and (ii) interventions that preserve the integrity of the wetlands, thereby 
conserving the biodiversity of global significance. 
A.  General 
2.  A team of international and domestic consultants will (i) review, analyze, and update the 
findings and recommendations of the midterm report of the Songhua River Flood, Wetland, and 
Biodiversity Management Project1; (ii) undertake socioeconomic, biophysical, institutional, and 
other analyses and assessments as detailed below; (iii) evaluate past experience and lessons 
learned in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), especially the United Nations Development 
Programme (UNDP)/Global Environment Facility (GEF) national Wetlands Project,  which has 
demonstration sites in the area, including the Honghe Nature Reserve, and in other countries in 
the region; and (iv) prepare a feasibility study report for an investment plan for integrated 
conservation  and  development  in  the  Sanjiang  Plains,  including  a  GEF  project  brief  and 
appendixes. In this context, the  team will review existing institutions policies and legislation 
pertaining to biodiversity conservation, and wetland protection and the progress made by the 
PRC  in  the  implementation  of  various  international  conventions  including  the  Biodiversity 
Convention and the Ramsar Convention.

B.  Specific Outline Terms of Reference 
4.  The team of consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Undertake  a  review  of  individual  wetland,  other  water  bodies  (rivers  and  lakes), 
commercial  forests,  and  related  natural  resources  sites  within  the  Sanjiang  Plains 
according  to  their  significance  in  terms  of  their  economic  potential  and  global 
biodiversity, including their importance as breeding or migratory refuges for globally 
threatened and endangered species.  Develop a prioritized list of critical sites based on 
criteria such as biodiversity importance; degree of threat; and potential for conservation 
and economic development activities, including poverty reduction. Undertake preliminary 
analyses of threats and pressures, and develop action plans to address major ones, 
(ii)  Analyze the potential impacts of existing and planned flood control measures, including 
infrastructure such as embankments, water storage and retention basins, reservoirs, and 
water diversion schemes, on wetland integrity and functioning and on biodiversity. Make 
recommendations for improving the hydrological balance and management of critical 
nature reserves.  Make recommendations for better integrating flood control and wetland 
conservation in sustainable water resources policies and plans, including the current 
flood management plan,  
(iii)  Assess the current status of forest resources, especially the fast growing commercial 
plantations under the jurisdiction of the Provincial Forestry Department (PFD), and 
determine the potential for their expansion, and the need and the means for introducing 
scientific management. This will include establishment of new fast-growing plantations 
with their management integrated with the existing plantations with the objective of 
ensuring self-sustainability of the sector within five years. The choice of species for new 
plantations will be determined on technical grounds and will be dictated by the site 
characteristics, growth characteristics, and potential for commercial use in the wood-
based industry sector of the province,  
(iv)  Undertake in-depth analysis of the integrated conservation and economic development 
approaches and their relevance to the protection, conservation, and management of 
Sanjiang Plains wetlands and forests, with specific reference to the activities proposed 
as  major  components.  This  will  include  an  analysis  of  the  proposed  institutional 
arrangements  for  implementation  to  ensure  that  the  proposed  investments  sustain 
production,  promote  ecotourism  and  local  community  development,  and  enhance 
conservation, 
(v)  Undertake  social  analysis  to  Identify  communities  living  in  the  Sanjiang  Plains,  in 
particular in and around nature reserves; assess their manner of dependence on the 
resource and links thereto, aspirations, and expectations; consult with communities to

C.  Reports 
5.  The  consultants  will  be  required  to  produce  four  reports.  Within  3  weeks  of 
commencement, they will prepare an inception report, based on site visits and review of 
available information, and on discussions with concerned officials. This report will include an 
evaluation of the current status of natural resources in the Sanjiang Plains, including protected 
areas (with specific reference to habitat for globally significant flora and fauna), forest areas and 
scope for their scientific management, water bodies (including rivers and lakes, fisheries and 
aquaculture), and others, as appropriate, with a view to integrating conservation with economic 
development and poverty reduction. The report will also include the proposed work program and 
a  logical  framework  (logframe)  illustrating  how  the  technical  assistance  objectives  will  be 
achieved.  It will be discussed at a tripartite meeting among the Government, ADB, and the 
consultants. A midterm report, providing an analysis of various socioeconomic, biophysical, 
institutional, and other aspects relevant to the ensuing Project together with information on and 
analysis of various investment options for integrated conservation and economic development, 
an updated logframe, and the work program for the remaining period of implementation, will be 
prepared within 2 months after the inception meeting and discussed at the midterm tripartite 
meeting. The tripartite meeting will guide the consultants regarding the most appropriate course 
of action for preparation of the draft final report, and agree on the proposed outline for the final 
report and the work program. The draft final report will be prepared within 2 months of midterm 
tripartite meeting and discussed at the final tripartite meeting, when an agreement will be 
reached on the objectives, scope, social and environmental aspects, economic and financial 
analyses,  implementation  arrangements,  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  (including 
cofinancing arrangements with GEF and others), and other relevant aspects of the ensuing 
Project. The final report will incorporate the comments and suggestions made at the meeting. All 
reports will be translated into Chinese.
